page.title: 10RUSHALL LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Rushall and Shelfield were recorded in the original Domesday Book; the former as a hide, six farms, two cottages and a mill, the latter as a hide of waste land. In the sixteenth century there was a road leading from Walsall to the Rushall mill. Rushall Hall was built in the twelth century and was involved in the civil war. In 1776 the Turnpike Trust widened the road to Walsall so traffic could pass through busy Rushall. A canal was opened in 1840 and later extended to Birmingham. In April 184 the South Staffs Railway Company opened a line from Walsall to Wichnor. Limepits, tanneries and coal mining provided work for local people. Much of the area, including Shelfield, Goscote and Blakenhall was mainly farmland and the twentieth century has seen the gradual encroachment of housing and industry.
